text:
Franklin Delano Roosevelt (1882-1945) was the 32nd President of the United States, serving an unprecedented four terms from 1933 to 1945. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential and successful presidents in American history.

Born on January 30, 1882, in Hyde Park, New York, Roosevelt was the only child of James and Sara Ann Roosevelt. He was a distant cousin of Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th President of the United States. Franklin's early life was marked by poor health, including the contraction of polio in 1921 at the age of 39, which left him paralyzed from the waist down.

Roosevelt graduated from Harvard University in 1904 and went on to study law at Columbia University. He became a successful businessman and investor, and served as the Assistant Secretary of the Navy from 1913 to 1920, during which he played a key role in the American naval buildup before World War I.

In 1921, Roosevelt was elected Governor of New York, a position he held for two terms until 1929. When the Great Depression hit the United States in 1929, Roosevelt was elected President in 1932, defeating incumbent Herbert Hoover in a landslide victory.

As President, Roosevelt implemented a series of programs and policies known as the New Deal, which aimed to alleviate the suffering of the Great Depression and reform the American economy. The New Deal included a range of measures, such as the creation of jobs programs, the establishment of social security, and the regulation of industry.

Roosevelt's leadership during World War II was also instrumental in the Allied victory. He played a key role in shaping American foreign policy, including the development of the Lend-Lease Act, which provided military aid to countries fighting against the Axis powers.

Roosevelt was elected to an unprecedented four terms as President, serving from 1933 to 1945. He died on April 12, 1945, just 11 months into his fourth term, at the age of 63. He was succeeded by Vice President Harry S. Truman.

Roosevelt's legacy is immense, and he is widely regarded as one of the most effective and influential presidents in American history. His leadership during the Great Depression and World War II helped to shape the modern American welfare state and cemented the United States' position as a global superpower.

U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, also known as FDR, was born on January 30, 1882, in Hyde Park, New York. He was the only child of James Roosevelt and Sara Ann Delano. FDR's distant cousin was Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th President of the United States.

FDR was a member of the wealthy and influential Roosevelt family. He grew up with a disability, contracting polio at the age of 39. This illness left him paralyzed from the waist down, but he refused to let it stop him from living a full life.

FDR studied at Groton School and then at Harvard University. He was a skilled student and enjoyed sports, particularly sailing and football. In 1905, he married his childhood sweetheart, Eleanor Roosevelt, who was the niece of Theodore Roosevelt.

FDR entered politics in 1911, serving as a member of the New York State Senate. In 1921, he became the Assistant Secretary of the Navy, a position he held until 1929. He was a strong supporter of President Woodrow Wilson and played a key role in the Democratic Party.

In 1932, FDR, then the Governor of New York, won the Democratic nomination for President and went on to defeat Republican candidate Herbert Hoover in a landslide election. He was re-elected in 1936, 1940, and 1944.

As President, FDR implemented a series of policies and reforms known as the New Deal, which aimed to address the economic crisis of the Great Depression. These policies included the establishment of Social Security, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

FDR also led the United States through World War II, providing strong leadership and guidance to the country during this time of crisis. He played a key role in shaping the post-war world order, including the formation of the United Nations.

FDR was the first President to be elected four times, and he was re-elected for a fourth term in 1944. However, he died on April 12, 1945, just 11 months into his fourth term, at his retreat in Warm Springs, Georgia. He was 63 years old at the time of his death.

Throughout his life, FDR was known for his charisma, his ability to connect with ordinary people, and his strong leadership. He remains one of the most beloved and influential presidents in American history.

In 1921, Roosevelt was elected as the Governor of New York, where he implemented numerous reforms, including a minimum wage, workers' compensation, and unemployment insurance. His success in New York earned him national recognition, and in 1932, he won the Democratic nomination for president.

As President, Roosevelt faced the Great Depression, which had left millions of Americans unemployed and struggling to make ends meet. He implemented a series of policies and programs known as the New Deal, which aimed to stimulate economic recovery and provide relief to those affected by the Depression. Some notable programs included the Works Progress Administration, the Civilian Conservation Corps, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

In addition to his domestic agenda, Roosevelt also played a crucial role in leading the United States through World War II. He served as the commander-in-chief of the U.S. military and worked closely with British Prime Minister Winston Churchill to coordinate Allied efforts against the Axis powers.

Roosevelt's leadership during World War II was instrumental in the Allied victory, and he played a key role in the Yalta Conference and the Potsdam Conference, where he met with Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to discuss post-war reorganization.

Throughout his life, Roosevelt was known for his charismatic leadership and his ability to connect with people. He was also known for his optimistic outlook and his famous phrase, "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself."

Roosevelt died on April 12, 1945, just a few months into his fourth term as president. He was succeeded by Vice President Harry S. Truman, who went on to play a significant role in the final stages of World War II and the early years of the Cold War.

Despite his passing, Roosevelt's legacy continues to be felt today. His New Deal programs and his leadership during World War II have had a lasting impact on American history, and he remains one of the most beloved and respected presidents in American history.

During his presidency, Roosevelt implemented a series of programs and policies known as the New Deal, which aimed to alleviate the suffering of the Great Depression and reform the American economy. Some notable accomplishments include:

* Establishing the Social Security system
* Creating the Works Progress Administration (WPA) and the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC)
* Implementing the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)
* Establishing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) to insure bank deposits

Roosevelt also led the country through World War II, playing a key role in shaping the Allied victory. He was the primary architect of the Lend-Lease Act, which provided economic aid to Allied nations, and he played a crucial role in the Yalta Conference, where the Allied leaders discussed post-war reorganization.

FDR died on April 12, 1945, just 11 months into his fourth term as President. He was 63 years old. His legacy is still celebrated today, and he remains one of the most beloved and influential leaders in American history.
